div.p: Sedentary dialect close to urban Tunisian and Libyan

Sicily is the largest island in the Mediterranean sea, separated from mainland Italy by the narrow strait of Messina and only 144 km off the North African coast. Today, apart from Italian, the Italo-Dalmatian Romance language Sicilian is also spoken.

When Sicily was conquered by the Aghlabids in the 9th century, it was inhabited by Roman and Byzantine Christians, and the population spoke Greek in the east and a Romance dialect or vulgar Latin in the west. Even before the conquest, Arabic was an important trade language. Immigration by North African arabophone Muslims and Jews as well as Berbers increased and continued when the Fatimids came to power at the beginning of the 10th century. There was never complete Islamization or Arabization of the island, and communities were either arabophone or bilingual; only a few communities in the East remained monolingual Greek speakers throughout.

The Jewish citizens of Sicily were better acculturated to the predominant Muslim culture and to a higher degree arabicized. The North African Jews were arabophone from the start and the Jewish population spoke Arabic until the end of the 15th century.

The nominally Fatimid Kalbite dynasty ruled increasingly independently. By the 11th century, their emirate had disintegrated into several principalities. The Normans, who had occupied Southern Italy, gained control over all of Sicily. However, Muslims were not pressured to convert to Christianity, and Latinization was as incomplete as the Arabization was before. In fact, Arab culture blossomed under Norman rule.

After Muslim revolts in the 13th century, many of them were deported to Lucera in Italy, but at this point, the domination of Arabic and Islam had already long vanished, and several theories exist as to why the Arab communities dissolved so completely and left a comparatively small trace on the Sicilian language as well, among them conversion to Christianity and emigration.

Sicily shows a magnificent mixture of Hellenic, Byzantine and Islamic art and architecture, as it was a melting pot of cultures and beautifully merged the best of each of them, as can be seen e.g. in the cathedral of Palermo, originally the Grand Mosque. The typical Sicilian cuisine is based on crops introduced by the Arabs, such as sugar cane, pistachios and bitter oranges.

The Kalbite Emirate of Sicily comprised Malta. The Maltese language developed from Arabic, albeit showing strong influence of a Romance superstrate. Some scholars argue that Maltese derived directly from Sicilian Arabic.

Some of our knowledge about Sicilian Arabic stems from laḥn-authors who set out to “correct” the dialect spoken by the people in reference to Classical Arabic. They viewed the dialect merely as an incorrect rendition of CA, neglecting the diglossic situation. There are also Middle Arabic documents of the Norman period, the so-called ǧarāˀid. From toponyms and anthroponyms, preserved in Greek and Latin script, conclusions about the vowel system can be drawn.
Cusa published a collection of Sicilian parchments in Arabic and ancient Greek, which has provided ample material for scholars, e.g. De Simone’s 1979 work on anthroponyms.
Blau 1968 firmly categorises Sicilian Arabic as a Western dialect primarily influenced by North African dialects, although Maltese and Sicilian do show some traits of the Mashriq-dialects.
Two works by Pellegrini 1972 and Caracausi 1983 look at Arabisms in modern Romance languages, particularly Sicilian. Both have also published other works on Arabic in Sicily.

Molan’s 1978 dissertation undertakes the reconstruction of Medieval Western dialects through the laḥn-literature. A monumental collection is the “Biblioteca Arabo-Sicula” of Amari 1982, comprising texts in Arabic that deal with various aspects of Sicilian culture and geography. It is not, however, a collection of Sicilian literary works, but a collection of texts on Sicily in a broader sense.

Agius has worked extensively on “Siculo-Arabic”, among other topics on the role of the laḥn-author Ibn Makkī (Agius 1994, Agius 1991), but also on the adverb (Agius 1992), terminology (Agius 1990, Agius 1987, Agius 1986) and the Siculo-Arabic origin of Maltese. Agius 1996 comprises references to the laḥn-literatur, a description of the sociolinguistic situation and deals with Romance and Greek interferences. It is the most comprehensive work on Sicilian Arabic. Agius proposes the development of a pidgin and later creolised Arabic alongside Romance or Greek.
Borruso 1991 examines Arabic poetry in Sicily, as does Miller 2019 and 2020, who revises Sicilian Arabic court poetry under Norman rule.

Although not a work on dialectology, Metcalfe 2014 gives a good overview of the linguistic change from Romance and Greek to Arabic and back to Romance, and he has also written the entry on Sicily in the EALL.
